p: To explain the division among groups in the LES, this article proposes that divisions between community groups can be interpreted as conflicts over temporal scale – existing present-day use of environmental amenities versus protection from future climate risks. A few scholars have documented rifts within environmental justice movements, such as debates over what should be the scale of anti-hazardous waste activism in Alabama (Alley et al., 1995) or the implications of race and class as bases of identification in social movement organizing in South Africa (Checker, 2004). How the empirical reality of climate change can add a dimension of difference within environmental justice movements, manifesting as a rift of temporal scale, is comparatively overlooked.
